titleStmt.title: Detecting Null Alleles With Vasarely Charts

analytic.title: Detecting Null Alleles With Vasarely Charts

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Microsatellite genotypes can have problems that are difficult to detect with existing tools. One such problem is null alleles. This paper presents a new visualization tool that helps to find and characterize these errors. The paper explains how the tool is used to analyze groups of genotypes and proposes other possible uses.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Microsatellite genotypes are an important part of many genetic studies [7,9,12,18]. At sites known as genetic markers, measurements are made for each patient in a population, and the resulting measurements constitute a microsatellite genotype. Each genotype comprises two alleles, identified by letter codes. When both alleles have the same value, the genotype is known as a homozygote; when they differ, as a heterozygote.

A confounding factor in microsatellite genotyping is the presence of null alleles, mutations in the DNA sequence that prevent detection of an allele. Such genotypes, viewed individually, are largely indistinguishable from homozygotes [1,10].
The possible alleles for a microsatellite genotype have a natural order, and detecting adjacent alleles can be problematic for some markers.

Detecting null alleles and similar problems requires analysis of groups of genotypes. Mendelian inheritance checking [11,16] is routinely used to detect genotyping errors, but it is unable to detect null alleles in certain types of patient populations [4,11,12]. This paper presents a graphical tool that facilitates detection of null alleles and similar problems.

div.head: PROBLEM
div.p: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium (HWE) asserts the independence of the two alleles in a diploid genotype. The likelihood that the second allele will take on a particular value is independent of the first allele. Because null alleles cause heterozygous genotypes to appear as homozygotes, their presence can be detected as excessive homozygosity in a population at equilibrium. Not only null alleles, but also other marker-specific problems can cause deviation from HWE. Thus, a tool that can help to characterize a marker's correspondence to HWE was needed.

div.head: ALTERNATIVES
div.p: Possible representations of how a marker's homozygosity differs from the expected include Chi-square and other statistical analyses [3,13] and scatterplots of measured versus expected genotype frequency. Measured genotype frequency is the count of patients with one particular pair of alleles divided by the total number of patients genotyped for the marker. The expected genotype frequency, based on HWE, is the product of the two allele frequencies. Since there is no meaningful order to the two alleles of a genotype, the expected frequency for heterozygotes is doubled [2]. Chi-square analysis is helpful, but somewhat weak at showing patterns of variation [5]. Although scatterplots can clearly show discrepancies between measured and expected frequency, linear axes limit their ability to show patterns involving pairs of alleles.

div.head: APPROACH
div.p: To overcome these limitations, the authors have devised the Vasarely chart. It is named after the Hungarian-born French artist Victor Vasarely (1908Vasarely ( -1997, whose optical art it resembles [8,14].

The chart is a simple grid of square cells, with the first allele defining the rows and the second allele, the columns. At the intersection between a row and a column, the expected genotype frequency is represented by shading the full cell. The measured frequency is represented by shading a circle, centered on the cell with a diameter that gives it comparable visual weight to the remaining cell (about 75% of the cell size).

The chart makes effective use of the eye's ability to detect curves against a linear background [19]. It also exploits sensitivity to intensity of shade [6] and pattern perception. [17,20] In the absence of null alleles or other problems distorting allele frequencies, the measured and expected genotype frequencies are nearly equal, so the circles have the same shade as their surrounding squares, and are therefore not seen as circles. Figure 1 shows a marker that closely conforms to HWE; circles are only slightly visible. 1 (carl_manaster, betsy_nanthakumar, phil_morin) @axyspharm.com The marker shown in Figure 2 has more visible circles than that in Figure 1, but the circles are faint, and there is no prominent pattern to the circles. The spottiness of this marker's chart is attributed to the presence of rare alleles. Where the expected frequency of a genotype is small, having one genotype more or fewer in a finite population can affect the chart's appearance. These markers are represented by a total of approximately 1,300 patients each. In the first marker, with ten alleles, these patients are distributed over 100 possible cells; in the second, with fifteen alleles, they are distributed over 225 possible cells. Although the allele frequencies of the first two markers differ, their charts share a similar pattern, dominated by squares.

Null alleles appear as dark circles along the identity diagonal, with light circles elsewhere. More frequent null alleles result in more pronounced circles. Figure 3 shows a marker with conspicuous null alleles. The marker shown in Figure 4 has the diagonal of dark circles, which initially suggests null alleles, but closer inspection reveals that the genotypes with lower-than-expected frequency are restricted to cells adjacent to the diagonal. This suggested poor resolution of adjacent alleles; a close review of the source data confirmed this.

div.head: PRACTICAL EXAMPLE
div.p: The marker shown in Figure 5 has a very dominant "B" allele. The image also indicates a significant deficit of A-B genotypes. This deficit confirmed a large number of errors for the marker, as detected through inheritance. It also provided insight into how to correct the errors. By reviewing the raw data, it became clear that many of the putative B-B genotypes were actually A-B genotypes, as the chart suggested. Correcting these calls (114 of 818 genotypes) resulted in almost complete elimination of errors detected through inheritance. In addition, many of the corrections repaired errors that could not have been detected with the available pedigree information.

The chart from the corrected data is shown in Figure 6. Although the A-B deficit is greatly reduced, light circles are still visible in the A-B positions, suggesting that some errors remain. Despite the remaining problems, application of the information gleaned from the chart has rescued a previously unusable marker. Since the expectation function is dependent on the number of alleles, changing B-B calls to A-B, which increases the number of A alleles, darkens the A-A background square as well as the A-B circles. This further reduces the visibility of circles on the chart. Other cells are similarly affected, but the changes are not detectable at this level of shading.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: We have experimented with several variations of this basic chart. People found the triangular half chart more difficult to read. Alternative color schemes were found to be more distracting than helpful. The chart is useful for entities numbering five to one hundred. Fewer rows make patterns hard to detect, and more rows make circles hard to detect. There may be some perceptual problems where, for example, a gray circle looks lighter against a dark square than a circle of the same shade against a light square, but such issues should not affect the chart's ability to show where measured values depart from expected values, the direction and rough magnitude of the departure.

Vasarely charts are effective at revealing patterns of variability. In one glance, the marker's allele distribution, "spottiness", and patterns of deviation from HWE can all be seen. Where such deviation exists, insights into the possible nature of errors are can be gleaned with little study.

Different markers have quite different allele frequency distributions, so the program that generates these charts lets users change shades to make the patterns apparent. Patterns such as the diagonal of dark circles indicating null alleles are therefore readily visible even against widely differing backgrounds.
As seen in the example, the charts can also provide insight into the specific nature of problems, identifying problem data.
Routine use of Vasarely charts exposes data quality issues that might not otherwise be seen, and helps to explain issues detected through other means.

div.head: SOFTWARE
div.p: A simple Macintosh program that generates Vasarely charts from formatted ASCII files is available from the author. It provides control over shading and cell size and supports printing and saving images in standard picture format. Pascal source code is also available.

div.head: OTHER POSSIBLE APPLICATIONS
div.p: Genotype frequencies are well represented by Vasarely charts for the following reasons:
• The entities (alleles) interact in pairs;
• The entities have a natural order;
• There is a modest number (5 -100) of entities;
• The quality (genotype frequency) exists for any pair of entities;
• The quality can be estimated for any pair of entities;
• The quality is continuous -big differences matter more than little differences.
Other data sets with these properties can benefit from representation on Vasarely charts.

The charts have been applied to allele inheritance. Here the entities are related individuals, and the quality is allele sharing between individuals. This has been problematic because estimation of allele sharing is more difficult than estimation of genotype frequency.

Vasarely charts can also be applied to hybridization experiments [15], with rows representing genes and columns, tissue types. The quality is expression; instead of measured and expected value, expression in normal tissue and in affected tissue determine the shades of squares and circles.

Since the data displayed in a Vasarely chart (measured and expected values for pairs of entities) is the same as that used in chi-square analysis, data sets that lend themselves to such analysis may also be fit subjects for Vasarely charts. Chi-square analysis yields summary numbers that are more amenable to automation than are these images, and Vasarely charts provide a better feel for the details of the data. The two methods are complementary.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: Vasarely charts are useful for detecting null alleles and other problems encountered in microsatellite genotyping. They can confirm problems detected through other means and provide insight into their nature. They can also detect problems that would not otherwise be apparent. Vasarely charts may have application to data sets with similar properties.

figure.figDesc: D E F G H I J K L M N O Normal Marker; Fifteen Alleles

figure.head: Figure 3 :
figure.figDesc: Marker with Null AllelesThis marker's chart differs distinctly from those of the two normal markers. The presence of circles is immediately apparent, showing strong departure from HWE. The pattern of circlesdark along the diagonal and light elsewhere -shows the nature of this departure; more homozygotes than expected, which is indicative of null alleles.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The authors are grateful for encouragement and assistance from several individuals. Jochen Hampe provided the essential initial motivation to write this paper. Mike Stewart made helpful clarifications regarding hybridization experiments. Nina Robinson's support and encouragement were indispensable.
